001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
005import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.FloatColors;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.Shaders;
007import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.TrigTools;
008
009import java.util.Random;
010
011import static com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils.floor;
012import static com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.Gamut.GAMUT_DATA;
013
014/**
015 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the Oklab color space.
016 * Oklab is a very new color space that builds on the same foundation as IPT, but seems to be better-calibrated for
017 * uniform lightness and colorfulness, instead of just the emphasis on uniform hue that IPT has. Relative to IPT, Oklab
018 * has a noticeably smaller range in chromatic channels (IPT's protan and tritan can range past 0.8 or as low as 0.35,
019 * but the similar A and B channels in Oklab don't stray past about 0.65 at the upper end, if that), but it does this so
020 * the difference between two Oklab colors is just the Euclidean distance between their components. A slight difference
021 * between Oklab and IPT here is that IPT shrinks the chromatic channels to store their -1 to 1 range in a color float's
022 * 0 to 1 range, then offsets the shrunken range from -0.5 to 0.5, to 0 to 1; Oklab does not need to shrink the range,
023 * and only offsets it in the same way (both just add 0.5).
024 * <br>
025 * Here's <a href="https://bottosson.github.io/posts/oklab/">Bj√∂rn Ottosson's original post introducing Oklab</a>.
026 * So far, <a href="https://raphlinus.github.io/color/2021/01/18/oklab-critique.html">it stood up to analysis by Raph
027 * Levien</a>, and seems to be gaining fans quickly.
028 */
029public class ColorTools {
030        /**
031         * No need to instantiate.
032         */
033        private ColorTools(){
034        }
035        /**
036         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, L (luminance or lightness), A
037         * (a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish, called protan in IPT), B (a chromatic component ranging
038         * from bluish to yellowish, called tritan in IPT), and alpha (or opacity). As long as you use a batch with
039         * {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderOklab} as its shader, colors passed with
040         * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)} will be interpreted as Oklab. L should be
041         * between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light
042         * colors (almost only white). A and B range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5.
043         * There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When A is high and B is low, the color is more
044         * purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when B is high and A is low, the color tends to be greenish,
045         * and when both are high it tends to be orange. When A and B are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.
046         * Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
047         * <br>
048         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
049         * L, A, and B, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original L,
050         * A, and B values if the original values were in the range that {@link #channelL(float)}, {@link #channelA(float)},
051         * and {@link #channelB(float)} return. You can use {@link #inGamut(float, float, float)} to check if a given set of
052         * L, A, and B values is in-gamut, that is, it can be converted to and from an RGB color without going out of the
053         * valid range. If you just want to enforce that a color is in-gamut, you can use
054         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}, which takes the same parameters this method does, or
055         * {@link #limitToGamut(float)} if you already have a packed float color that could be out-of-gamut.
056         *
057         * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of Oklab, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
058         * @param a     0f to 1f, protan or A component of Oklab, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
059         * @param b     0f to 1f, tritan or B component of Oklab, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
060         * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
061         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
062         */
063        public static float oklab(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
064                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (b * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
065                                | ((int) (a * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (l * 255) & 0xFF));
066        }
067
068
069        /**
070         * An approximation of the cube-root function for float inputs and outputs.
071         * This can be about twice as fast as {@link Math#cbrt(double)}. This
072         * version does not tolerate negative inputs, because in the narrow use
073         * case it has in this class, it never is given negative inputs.
074         * <br>
075         * Has very low relative error (less than 1E-9) when inputs are uniformly
076         * distributed between 0 and 512, and absolute mean error of less than
077         * 1E-6 in the same scenario. Uses a bit-twiddling method similar to one
078         * presented in Hacker's Delight and also used in early 3D graphics (see
079         * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_inverse_square_root for more, but
080         * this code approximates cbrt(x) and not 1/sqrt(x)). This specific code
081         * was originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his "Stand-alone-junk"
082         * repo: https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/master/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197 .
083         * It's worth noting that while hardware instructions for finding the
084         * square root of a float have gotten extremely fast, the same is not
085         * true for the cube root (which has to allow negative inputs), so while
086         * the bit-twiddling inverse square root is no longer a beneficial
087         * optimization on current hardware, this does seem to help.
088         * <br>
089         * This is used when converting from RGB to Oklab, as an intermediate step.
090         * @param x any non-negative finite float to find the cube root of
091         * @return the cube root of x, approximated
092         */
093        private static float cbrtPositive(float x) {
094                int ix = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(x);
095                final float x0 = x;
096                ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
097                ix += (ix>>>4);
098                ix += (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0;
099                x  = NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(ix);
100                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
101                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
102                return x;
103        }
104
105        /**
106         * Used when converting from Oklab to RGB, as an intermediate step.
107         * Really just {@code x * x * x}.
108         * @param x one of the LMS Prime channels to be converted to LMS
109         * @return an LMS channel value, which can be converted to RGB
110         */
111        private static float cube(final float x) {
112                return x * x * x;
113        }
114
115        /**
116         * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, approximating with gamma 2.0.
117         * Really just {@code component * component}.
118         * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
119         * @return a linear version of component
120         */
121        private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
122                return component * component;
123        }
124
125        /**
126         * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using gamma 2.0.
127         * Really just a float version of the square root of component.
128         * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
129         * @return a non-linear version of component
130         */
131        private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
132                return (float)Math.sqrt(component);
133        }
134
135        /**
136         * Changes the curve of a requested L value so that it matches the internally-used curve. This takes a curve with a
137         * very-dark area similar to sRGB (a very small one), and makes it significantly larger. This is typically used on
138         * "to Oklab" conversions.
139         * @param L lightness, from 0 to 1 inclusive
140         * @return an adjusted L value that can be used internally
141         */
142        public static float forwardLight(final float L) {
143        final float shape = 0.64516133f, turning = 0.95f;
144        final float d = turning - L;
145                float r;
146        if(d < 0)
147            r = ((1f - turning) * (L - 1f)) / (1f - (L + shape * d)) + 1f;
148        else
149            r = (turning * L) / (1e-20f + (L + shape * d));
150                return r * r;
151    }
152
153//      public static float forwardLight(final float L) {
154//              return (L - 1.004f) / (1f - L * 0.4285714f) + 1.004f;
155//      }
156
157        /**
158         * Changes the curve of the internally-used lightness when it is output to another format. This makes the very-dark
159         * area smaller, matching (kind-of) the curve that the standard sRGB lightness uses. This is typically used on "from
160         * Oklab" conversions.
161         * @param L lightness, from 0 to 1 inclusive
162         * @return an adjusted L value that can be fed into a conversion to RGBA or something similar
163         */
164
165    public static float reverseLight(float L) {
166                L = (float) Math.sqrt(L);
167        final float shape = 1.55f, turning = 0.95f;
168        final float d = turning - L;
169                float r;
170        if(d < 0)
171            r = ((1f - turning) * (L - 1f)) / (1f - (L + shape * d)) + 1f;
172        else
173            r = (turning * L) / (1e-20f + (L + shape * d));
174                return r;
175    }
176
177//      public static float reverseLight(final float L) {
178//              return (L - 0.993f) / (1f + L * 0.75f) + 0.993f;
179//      }
180
181        /**
182         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
183         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
184         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
185         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
186         */
187        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
188        {
189                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
190                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
191                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
192                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
193                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
194                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
195                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
196                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
197                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
198                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
199                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
200        }
201
202        /**
203         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
204         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
205         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
206         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
207         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
208         */
209        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
210        {
211                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
212                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
213                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
214                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
215                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
216                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
217                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
218                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
219                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
220                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
221                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
222        }
223
224        /**
225         * Writes an Oklab-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)})
226         * into an RGBA8888 Color as used by libGDX (called {@code editing}).
227         * @param editing a libGDX color that will be filled in-place with an RGBA conversion of {@code packed}
228         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
229         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
230         */
231        public static Color toColor(Color editing, final float packed)
232        {
233                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
234                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
235                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
236                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
237                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
238                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
239                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
240                editing.r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
241                editing.g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
242                editing.b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
243                editing.a = (decoded >>> 25) * 0x1.020408p-7f; // this is 1/127 as a float
244                return editing.clamp();
245        }
246
247        /**
248         * Writes an Oklab-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)})
249         * into an Oklab-format Color called {@code editing}. This is mostly useful if the rest of your application expects
250         * colors in Oklab format, such as because you use {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderOklab} or {@link ColorfulBatch}.
251         * <br>
252         * Internally, this simply calls {@link Color#abgr8888ToColor(Color, float)} and returns the edited Color.
253         * @param editing a libGDX Color that will be filled in-place with the color {@code oklab}, unchanged from its color space
254         * @param oklab a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
255         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
256         */
257        public static Color toOklabColor(Color editing, final float oklab){
258                Color.abgr8888ToColor(editing, oklab);
259                return editing;
260        }
261
262        /**
263         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
264         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
265         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
266         */
267        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
268                final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
269                final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
270                final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
271
272                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
273                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
274                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
275
276                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
277                                      Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
278                                                                                  (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
279                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
280                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
281                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
282        }
283
284        /**
285         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
286         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
287         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
288         */
289        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
290                final int abgr = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
291                final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
292                final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
293                final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
294                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
295                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
296                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
297                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
298                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
299                                                                                  (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
300                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
301                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
302                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
303        }
304
305        // original multipliers for LMS when obtaining the non-shrunken A and B values:
306        //+0.2104542553 +0.7936177850 -0.0040720468
307        //+1.9779984951 -2.4285922050 +0.4505937099
308        //+0.0259040371 +0.7827717662 -0.8086757660
309
310        // shrunken multipliers:
311        //+0.2104542553 +0.7936177850 -0.0040720468
312        //+0.9889992500 -1.2142961000 +0.2252968500
313        //+0.0129520185 +0.3913858800 -0.4043378800
314
315        /**
316         * Takes a libGDX Color that uses RGBA8888 channels and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
317         * @param color a libGDX RGBA8888 Color
318         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
319         */
320        public static float fromColor(final Color color) {
321                final float r = forwardGamma(color.r);
322                final float g = forwardGamma(color.g);
323                final float b = forwardGamma(color.b);
324                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
325                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
326                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
327                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
328                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
329                                                                                  (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
330                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
331                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
332                                                | ((int)(color.a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
333        }
334
335        /**
336         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
337         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
338         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
339         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
340         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
341         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
342         */
343        public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
344                r = forwardGamma(r);
345                g = forwardGamma(g);
346                b = forwardGamma(b);
347                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
348                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
349                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
350                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
351                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
352                                                                                  (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
353                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
354                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
355                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
356        }
357
358        /**
359         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
360         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
361         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
362         */
363        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
364        {
365                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
366                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
367                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
368                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
369                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
370                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
371                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
372                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
373        }
374
375        /**
376         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
377         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
378         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
379         */
380        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
381        {
382                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
383                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
384                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
385                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
386                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
387                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
388                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
389                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
390        }
391
392        /**
393         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
394         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
395         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
396         */
397        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
398        {
399                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
400                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
401                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
402                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
403                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
404                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
405                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
406                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
407        }
408
409        /**
410         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
411         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
412         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
413         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
414         */
415        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
416        {
417                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
418        }
419
420        /**
421         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
422         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
423         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
424         */
425        public static float red(final float encoded)
426        {
427                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
428                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
429                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
430                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
431                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
432                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
433                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
434                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
435        }
436
437        /**
438         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
439         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
440         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
441         */
442        public static float green(final float encoded)
443        {
444                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
445                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
446                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
447                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
448                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
449                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
450                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
451                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
452        }
453
454        /**
455         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
456         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
457         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
458         */
459        public static float blue(final float encoded)
460        {
461                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
462                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
463                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
464                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
465                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
466                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
467                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
468                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
469        }
470
471        /**
472         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
473         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
474         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
475         */
476        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
477        {
478                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
479        }
480
481        /**
482         * Gets the "chroma" or "colorfulness" of a given Oklab color. Chroma is similar to saturation in that grayscale
483         * values have 0 saturation and 0 chroma, while brighter colors have high saturation and chroma. The difference is
484         * that colors that are perceptually more-colorful have higher chroma than colors that are perceptually
485         * less-colorful, regardless of hue, whereas saturation changes its meaning depending on the hue and lightness. That
486         * is, the most saturated color for a given hue and lightness always has a saturation of 1, but if that color
487         * isn't perceptually very colorful (as is the case for very dark and very light colors), it will have a chroma that
488         * is much lower than the maximum. The result of this method can't be negative, grayscale values have very close to
489         * 0 chroma, and the most colorful values (close to cyan) should have 0.334f chroma.
490         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
491         * @return a float between 0.0f and 0.334f that represents how colorful the given value is
492         */
493        public static float chroma(final float encoded) {
494                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
495                final float a = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1FE) - 0xFF)  * 0x1p-8f;
496                final float b = ((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1FE) - 0xFF) * 0x1p-8f;
497                return (float) Math.sqrt(a * a + b * b);
498        }
499
500        /**
501         * Given a hue and lightness, this gets the (approximate) maximum chroma possible for that hue-lightness
502         * combination. This is useful to know the bounds of {@link #chroma(float)}. This should be no greater
503         * than 0.334f .
504         * @param hue the hue, typically between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
505         * @param lightness the lightness, clamped between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
506         * @return the maximum possible chroma for the given hue and lightness, between 0.0f and 0.334f
507         */
508        public static float chromaLimit(final float hue, final float lightness){
509                final int idx = (int) (Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f) * 255.999f) << 8
510                                | (int) (256f * (hue - floor(hue)));
511                return (GAMUT_DATA[idx] + 1.5f) * 0x1p-8f;
512        }
513
514        /**
515         * Gets a color as an Oklab packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
516         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
517         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
518         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
519         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
520         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
521         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
522         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
523         * <br>
524         * This method considers its hue, saturation, and lightness parameters as the HSL color space does. You may instead
525         * want the method {@link #oklabByHSL(float, float, float, float)}, which treats lightness exactly as Oklab does,
526         * and handles hue and saturation with the Oklab color solid (which is shaped oddly) instead of the HSL color solid
527         * (which is a bicone, with a wide cone pointing up attached at the base to another wide cone pointing down).
528         * Using oklabByHSL() should be faster in many cases, and the lightness handling alone may be a reason to use it.
529         * There is also {@link #oklabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which may be preferable if you want a specific
530         * amount of chroma (colorful-ness) and no greater.
531         *
532         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
533         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
534         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
535         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
536         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
537         */
538        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
539                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
540                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
541                } else {
542                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
543                }
544        }
545
546        /**
547         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color as HSL would calculate it, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f,
548         * inclusive. This is different from {@link #chroma(float)}; see that method's documentation for details. It is also
549         * different from {@link #oklabSaturation(float)}, which gets the saturation as Oklab understands it rather than how
550         * HSL understands it.
551         *
552         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
553         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
554         */
555        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
556                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
557                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
558                if(Math.abs(L - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
559                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
560                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
561                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
562                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
563                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
564                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
565                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
566                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
567                float x, y, w;
568                if(g < b) {
569                        x = b;
570                        y = g;
571                }
572                else {
573                        x = g;
574                        y = b;
575                }
576                if(r < x) {
577                        w = r;
578                }
579                else {
580                        w = x;
581                        x = r;
582                }
583                return x - Math.min(w, y);
584        }
585
586        /**
587         * Defined as per HSL; normally you only need {@link #channelL(float)} to get accurate lightness for Oklab. You can
588         * also use {@link #oklabLightness(float)}, which is an alias for channelL(). This ranges from 0.0f (black) to 1.0f
589         * (white).
590         *
591         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
592         * @return the lightness of the given color as HSL would calculate it
593         */
594        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
595                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
596                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
597                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
598                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
599                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
600                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
601                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
602                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
603                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
604                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
605                float x, y, w;
606                if(g < b) {
607                        x = b;
608                        y = g;
609                }
610                else {
611                        x = g;
612                        y = b;
613                }
614                if(r < x) {
615                        w = r;
616                }
617                else {
618                        w = x;
619                        x = r;
620                }
621                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
622                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
623        }
624
625        /**
626         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
627         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased). You can also use {@link #oklabHue(float)}, which
628         * positions the different hues at different values, somewhat, from this, but is more accurate to how Oklab handles
629         * hues.
630         *
631         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
632         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
633         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
634         */
635        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
636                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
637                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
638                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
639                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
640                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
641                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
642                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
643                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
644                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
645                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
646                float x, y, z, w;
647                if(g < b) {
648                        x = b;
649                        y = g;
650                        z = -1f;
651                        w = 2f / 3f;
652                }
653                else {
654                        x = g;
655                        y = b;
656                        z = 0f;
657                        w = -1f / 3f;
658                }
659                if(r < x) {
660                        z = w;
661                        w = r;
662                }
663                else {
664                        w = x;
665                        x = r;
666                }
667                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
668                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
669        }
670
671        /**
672         * The "L" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
673         * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
674         *
675         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
676         * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
677         */
678        public static float channelL(final float encoded)
679        {
680                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
681        }
682
683        /**
684         * The "A" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the B channel describes the
685         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If A is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
686         * blue; if A is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the A of a color with
687         * {@link #raiseA(float, float)} and {@link #lowerA(float, float)}.
688         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
689         * @return the A value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
690         */
691        public static float channelA(final float encoded)
692        {
693                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
694        }
695
696        /**
697         * The "B" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the A channel describes the
698         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If B is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
699         * blue or purple; if B is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
700         * the B of a color with {@link #raiseB(float, float)} and {@link #lowerB(float, float)}.
701         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
702         * @return the B value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
703         */
704        public static float channelB(final float encoded)
705        {
706                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
707        }
708
709        /**
710         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
711         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not Oklab! Takes
712         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
713         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color with methods like
714         * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)}. The float is likely to be different from the
715         * result of {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity are all 0.
716         * This won't allocate any objects.
717         * <br>
718         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
719         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
720         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
721         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
722         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
723         * <br>
724         * You may want {@link #editOklab(float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float)} instead, which
725         * adjusts the L, A, B, and alpha channels directly instead of converting to HSL and back.
726         *
727         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
728         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
729         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
730         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
731         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
732         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
733         */
734        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
735                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
736                final float L = Math.min(Math.max(light + reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f), 0f), 1f);
737                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 25) * (1f / 127f), 0f), 1f);
738                if (L <= 0.001f)
739                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
740                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
741                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
742                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
743                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
744                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
745                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
746                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
747                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
748                float x, y, z, w;
749                if(g < b) {
750                        x = b;
751                        y = g;
752                        z = -1f;
753                        w = 2f / 3f;
754                }
755                else {
756                        x = g;
757                        y = b;
758                        z = 0f;
759                        w = -1f / 3f;
760                }
761                if(r < x) {
762                        z = w;
763                        w = r;
764                }
765                else {
766                        w = x;
767                        x = r;
768                }
769                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
770                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
771                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
772                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
773                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
774        }
775
776        /**
777         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
778         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
779         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
780         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
781         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
782         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
783         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
784         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
785         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
786         */
787        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
788                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
789                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
790        }
791
792        /**
793         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
794         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
795         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
796         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
797         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
798         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
799         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
800         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
801         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
802         */
803        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
804                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
805                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
806        }
807
808        /**
809         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
810         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
811         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
812         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
813         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
814         * alpha and L of start as-is.
815         * @see #lowerA(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
816         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
817         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
818         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
819         */
820        public static float raiseA(final float start, final float change) {
821                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
822                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
823        }
824
825        /**
826         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
827         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
828         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
829         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
830         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
831         * L of start as-is.
832         * @see #raiseA(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
833         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
834         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
835         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
836         */
837        public static float lowerA(final float start, final float change) {
838                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
839                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
840        }
841
842        /**
843         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
844         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
845         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
846         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
847         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
848         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
849         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
850         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
851         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
852         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
853         */
854        public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
855                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
856                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
857        }
858
859        /**
860         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
861         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
862         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
863         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
864         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
865         * alpha and L of start as-is.
866         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
867         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
868         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
869         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
870         */
871        public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
872                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
873                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
874        }
875
876        /**
877         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
878         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
879         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
880         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
881         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
882         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
883         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
884         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
885         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
886         */
887        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
888                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
889                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
890        }
891
892        /**
893         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
894         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
895         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
896         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
897         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
898         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
899         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
900         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
901         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
902         */
903        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
904                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
905                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
906        }
907
908        /**
909         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
910         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
911         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes A and B; it leaves L and alpha alone, unlike
912         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes L.
913         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
914         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
915         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
916         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
917         */
918        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
919                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
920                return oklab((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
921                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
922                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
923                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
924        }
925
926        /**
927         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
928         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
929         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only A and B. Higher values for {@code change} can
930         * force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}.
931         * The alpha never changes.
932         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
933         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
934         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
935         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
936         */
937        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
938                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
939                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
940                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
941                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
942                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
943        }
944
945        /**
946         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast with,
947         * gets a packed float Oklab color with roughly inverted L but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B
948         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
949         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for L values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
950         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
951         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the L unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
952         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
953         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
954         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
955         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
956         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
957         *                     this is the color that will be adjusted
958         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
959         *                            the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
960         * @return a different Oklab packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
961         */
962        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
963        {
964                final int bits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
965                                contrastBits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
966                                L = (bits & 0xff),
967                                A = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
968                                B = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
969                                cL = (contrastBits & 0xff),
970                                cA = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
971                                cB = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
972                if((A - cA) * (A - cA) + (B - cB) * (B - cB) >= 0x10000)
973                        return mainColor;
974                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((bits & 0xFEFFFF00) | (int) (cL < 128 ? L * 0.45f + 140 : 127 - L * 0.45f));
975        }
976
977        /**
978         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast
979         * with, gets a packed float Oklab color with L that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s L,
980         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
981         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
982         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
983         * <br>
984         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
985         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
986         * averages the original L of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
987         * @param mainColor a packed Oklab float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
988         * @param contrastingColor a packed Oklab float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the L of this
989         * @return a different packed Oklab float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
990         */
991        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
992        {
993                final int main = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
994                return limitToGamut(NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
995        }
996
997        /**
998         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's L and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
999         * with the original L. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
1000         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
1001         * @param mainColor a packed Oklab float color
1002         * @return a different packed Oklab float color, with its L channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
1003         */
1004        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
1005                final int oklab = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
1006                return limitToGamut(NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((oklab & 0xFEFFFF00) | (oklab + 128 & 0xFF) + (oklab & 0xFF) >>> 1));
1007        }
1008
1009        /**
1010         * Makes the additive Oklab color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
1011         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
1012         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
1013         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
1014         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
1015         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
1016         * @return an Oklab float color between gray and {@code color}
1017         */
1018        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
1019                final int e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color),
1020                                sL = 0x80, sA = 0x80, sB = 0x80,
1021                                eL = (e & 0xFF), eA = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eB = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
1022                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF)
1023                                | (((int) (sA + fraction * (eA - sA)) & 0xFF) << 8)
1024                                | (((int) (sB + fraction * (eB - sB)) & 0xFF) << 16)
1025                                | (eAlpha << 24));
1026        }
1027
1028        /**
1029         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
1030         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
1031         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
1032         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
1033         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the L, A, and B of the
1034         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
1035         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers A and B extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while L goes from 0 to 1,
1036         * but only internally for measuring distance).
1037         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
1038         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
1039         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
1040         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
1041         */
1042        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
1043                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color);
1044                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1045                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1046                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1047                final float limit = variance * variance;
1048                float dist, x, y, z;
1049                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
1050                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1051                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1052                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1053                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
1054                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
1055                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += L, y = (A + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (B + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
1056                                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
1057                                        | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
1058                }
1059                return color;
1060        }
1061
1062        /**
1063         * Given a 1D int index between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive), this treats the 1D index as two parts (lightness and
1064         * hue angle, both from 0 to 255) and gets the distance from grayscale to the edge of the gamut at that lightness
1065         * and hue. The index can be constructed from a lightness value {@code L} from 0 to 255, and a hue value {@code H}
1066         * from 0 to 255 with: {@code (L << 8 | H)} or the simpler equivalent {@code (L * 256 + H)}. These assume L and H
1067         * have been limited to the 0 to 255 range already. This does not bounds-check index. Because hue is not typically
1068         * measured between 0 and 255, getting that value is a bit different; you can use
1069         * {@link TrigTools#atan2_(float, float)} (with an Oklab color's B for y, then its A for x) and multiply it by 256
1070         * to get H.
1071         * <br>
1072         * The distance this returns is a byte between 0 and 84 (both inclusive), as the Euclidean distance from the center
1073         * grayscale value at the lightness in the index, to the edge of the gamut at the same lightness, along the hue in
1074         * the index. This is measured in a space from -1 to 1 for both A and B, with the 0 in the center meaning grayscale,
1075         * and multiplied by 256 to get a meaningful byte value. To return to the A and B values Oklab uses here, you would
1076         * need to use some trigonometry on the hue (if it's in the 0 to 1 range, you can call
1077         * {@link TrigTools#cos_(float)} on the hue to almost get A, and {@link TrigTools#sin_(float)} to almost get B),
1078         * then multiply each of those by the distance, divide each by 256.0, and add 0.5.
1079         * <br>
1080         * Only intended for the narrow cases where external code needs read-only access to the internal Oklab gamut data.
1081         * The gamut data is quite large (it is in a 71 KB source file containing only the gamut, while the entire IPT_HQ
1082         * ColorTools file is 56 KB, and includes everything else except a gamut table), so it's better to have
1083         * direct read access to it without being able to accidentally rewrite it.
1084         * @param index must be between 0 and 65535; the upper 8 bits are lightness and the lower 8 are hue angle.
1085         * @return a byte (always between 0 and 84, inclusive) representing the Euclidean distance between a grayscale value and the most saturated value possible, using the above measurements
1086         */
1087        public static byte getRawGamutValue(int index){
1088                return GAMUT_DATA[index];
1089        }
1090
1091        /**
1092         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as Oklab, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1093         * @param packed a packed float color as Oklab
1094         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1095         */
1096        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
1097        {
1098                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1099                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 255f;
1100                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127f) / 255f;
1101                final float g = GAMUT_DATA[(decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int)(256f * TrigTools.atan2_(B, A))];
1102                return g * g * 0x1p-18 + 0x1p-14 >= (A * A + B * B);
1103        }
1104
1105        /**
1106         * Returns true if the given Oklab values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1107         * @param L lightness channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1108         * @param A green-to-red chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1109         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1110         * @return true if the given Oklab channels can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1111         */
1112        public static boolean inGamut(float L, float A, float B)
1113        {
1114                A = ((int) (A * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1115                B = ((int) (B * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1116                final float g = GAMUT_DATA[((int) (L * 255) & 0xFF) << 8 | (int)(256f * TrigTools.atan2_(B, A))];
1117                return g * g * 0x1p-18 + 0x1p-14 >= (A * A + B * B);
1118
1119                ////This was the old code for this inGamut(), which was subtly different from the other inGamut() when called
1120                /// on a packed float. The packed floats can go ever-so-slightly towards or away from the edge.
1121//              A = (A - 0.5f);
1122//              B = (B - 0.5f);
1123//              final byte g = GAMUT_DATA[((int)(L * 255.999f) << 8) | (int)(256f * TrigTools.atan2_(B, A))];
1124//              return g * g * 0x1p-16 >= (A * A + B * B);
1125
1126        }
