1127
1128        /**
1129         * Gets the color with the same L as the Oklab color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
1130         * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
1131         * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
1132         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; does not need to be in-gamut
1133         * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
1134         * @see #limitToGamut(float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation for out-of-gamut colors.
1135         */
1136        public static float maximizeSaturation(final float packed) {
1137                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1138                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1139                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1140                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
1141                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1142                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1143                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1144                                (decoded & 0xFE0000FF) |
1145                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1146                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16);
1147        }
1148        /**
1149         * Gets the color with the same L as the Oklab color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
1150         * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
1151         * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
1152         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1153         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1154         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1155         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1156         * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
1157         * @see #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation
1158         * for out-of-gamut colors.
1159         */
1160        public static float maximizeSaturation(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1161                L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
1162                A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f;
1163                B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f;
1164                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1165                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
1166                final int idx = (int) (L * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1167                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1168                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1169                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1170                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1171                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1172                                                (int) (L * 255.999f));
1173        }
1174
1175        /**
1176         * Gets the hue of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands hue rather than how HSL does.
1177         * This is different from {@link #hue(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
1178         * and 1 (exclusive).
1179         *
1180         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1181         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive) that represents hue in the Oklab color space
1182         */
1183        public static float oklabHue(final float packed) {
1184                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1185                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1186                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1187                return TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
1188        }
1189
1190        /**
1191         * Gets the saturation of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands saturation rather than how HSL does.
1192         * Saturation here is a fraction of the chroma limit (see {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}) for a given hue and
1193         * lightness, and is between 0 and 1 almost all the time. Saturation should always be between 0 (inclusive) and 1
1194         * (inclusive).
1195         *
1196         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1197         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents saturation in the Oklab color space
1198         */
1199        public static float oklabSaturation(final float packed) {
1200                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1201                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1202                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1203                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
1204                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1205                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] + 1.5f;
1206                return dist == 3.5f ? 0f : (A * A + B * B) * 4f / (dist * dist);
1207        }
1208
1209        /**
1210         * Gets the lightness of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands lightness rather than how HSL does.
1211         * This is different from {@link #lightness(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
1212         * and 1 (inclusive).
1213         * <br>
1214         * This is the same as {@link #channelL(float)}.
1215         *
1216         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1217         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents lightness in the Oklab color space
1218         */
1219        public static float oklabLightness(final float packed){
1220                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed) & 0xff) / 255f;
1221        }
1222
1223        /**
1224         * A different way to specify an Oklab color, using hue, saturation, lightness, and alpha like a normal HSL(A) color
1225         * but calculating them directly in the Oklab color space. This is more efficient than
1226         * {@link #floatGetHSL(float, float, float, float)}, but for colors with less than 0.5f lightness, it can be very
1227         * unpredictable in how it handles saturation. Most colors between 0.5 and 0.75 hue that also have less than 0.5
1228         * lightness are extremely desaturated and close to gray, regardless of what you give for saturation, and these
1229         * colors suddenly jump to very saturated around 0.75 hue and higher. To avoid this issue, you may prefer using
1230         * {@link #oklabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which takes an absolute chroma as opposed to the saturation here
1231         * (which is a fraction of the maximum chroma).
1232         * <br>
1233         * Note that this takes a different value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just
1234         * like its {@code saturation} and the method {@link #saturation(float)}, and {@code lightness} and the method
1235         * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
1236         * {@link #channelL(float)}, but the saturation here refers to what fraction the chroma should be of the maximum
1237         * chroma for the given hue and lightness. You can use {@link #oklabHue(float)}, {@link #oklabSaturation(float)},
1238         * and {@link #oklabLightness(float)} to get the hue, saturation, and lightness values from an existing color that
1239         * this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
1240         * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
1241         * @param saturation will be clamped between 0 and 1
1242         * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
1243         * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
1244         * @return a packed Oklab float color that tries to match the requested hue, saturation, and lightness
1245         */
1246        public static float oklabByHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float alpha) {
1247                lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
1248                saturation = Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f);
1249                hue -= floor(hue);
1250                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1251                final int idx = (int) (lightness * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1252                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * saturation * 0.5f;
1253                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1254                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1255                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1256                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1257                                                (int) (lightness * 255.999f));
1258        }
1259
1260        /**
1261         * A different way to specify an Oklab color, using hue, chroma, lightness, and alpha something like a normal HSL(A)
1262         * color but calculating them directly in the Oklab color space. This has you specify the desired chroma directly,
1263         * as obtainable with {@link #chroma(float)}, rather than the saturation, which is a fraction of the maximum chroma
1264         * (saturation is what {@link #oklabByHSL(float, float, float, float)} uses). Note that this takes a different value
1265         * for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just like {@code lightness} and the method
1266         * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
1267         * {@link #channelL(float)}. If you use this to get two colors with the same chroma and lightness, but different
1268         * hue, then the resulting colors should have similar colorfulness unless one or both chroma values exceeded the
1269         * gamut limit (you can get this limit with {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}). If a chroma value given is greater
1270         * than the chroma limit, this clamps chroma to that limit. You can use {@link #oklabHue(float)},
1271         * {@link #chroma(float)}, and {@link #oklabLightness(float)} to get the hue, chroma, and lightness values from an
1272         * existing color that this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
1273         * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
1274         * @param chroma will be clamped between 0 and the maximum chroma possible for the given hue and lightness
1275         * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
1276         * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
1277         * @return a packed Oklab float color that tries to match the requested hue, chroma, and lightness
1278         */
1279        public static float oklabByHCL(float hue, float chroma, float lightness, float alpha) {
1280                lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
1281                chroma = Math.max(chroma, 0f);
1282                hue -= floor(hue);
1283                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1284                final int idx = (int) (lightness * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1285                final float dist = Math.min(chroma * 127.5f, GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f);
1286                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1287                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1288                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1289                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1290                                                (int) (lightness * 255.999f));
1291        }
1292
1293        /**
1294         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1295         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is.
1296         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; often this color is not in-gamut
1297         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1298         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1299         */
1300        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
1301                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1302                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1303                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1304                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
1305                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1306                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1307                if (dist * dist >= (A * A + B * B))
1308                        return packed;
1309                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1310                                (decoded & 0xFE0000FF) |
1311                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1312                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16);
1313        }
1314
1315        /**
1316         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1317         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is. This always produces
1318         * an opaque color.
1319         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1320         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1321         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1322         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1323         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1324         */
1325        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B) {
1326                return limitToGamut(L, A, B, 1f);
1327        }
1328        /**
1329         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1330         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is.
1331         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1332         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1333         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1334         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1335         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1336         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1337         */
1338        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1339                L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
1340                A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f);
1341                B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f);
1342                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1343                final float A2 = (A - 0.5f);
1344                final float B2 = (B - 0.5f);
1345                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2_(B2, A2);
1346                final int idx = (int) (L * 255.999f) << 8 | (int)(256f * hue);
1347                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1348                if(dist * dist * 0x1p-16f + 0x1p-14f >= (A2 * A2 + B2 * B2))
1349                        return oklab(L, A, B, alpha);
1350                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1351                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1352                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1353                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1354                                                (int) (L * 255.999f));
1355        }
1356
1357        /**
1358         * Given a packed float Oklab color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add"
1359         * parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1360         * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. This clamps the
1361         * resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
1362         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
1363         * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1364         * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1365         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1366         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1367         * @return a packed float Oklab color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1368         */
1369        public static float editOklab(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha) {
1370                return editOklab(encoded, addL, addA, addB, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
1371        }
1372        /**
1373         * Given a packed float Oklab color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by first multiplying each channel by
1374         * the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping. This means
1375         * the lightness value {@code L} is multiplied by {@code mulL}, then has {@code addL} added, and then is clamped to
1376         * the normal range for L (0 to 1). This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1377         * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged, or a value of 1 for any
1378         * "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this manipulates A and B in the -0.5 to 0.5 range, so if you
1379         * multiply by a small number like {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a less-saturated color, and if you multiply
1380         * by a larger number like {@code 4f}, then you will get a much more-saturated color. This clamps the resulting
1381         * color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
1382         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
1383         * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1384         * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1385         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1386         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1387         * @param mulL how much to multiply the L channel by; should be non-negative
1388         * @param mulA how much to multiply the A channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1389         * @param mulB how much to multiply the B channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1390         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
1391         * @return a packed float Oklab color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1392         */
1393        public static float editOklab(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha,
1394                                                                  float mulL, float mulA, float mulB, float mulAlpha) {
1395                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1396                float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1397                float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1398                float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1399                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
1400
1401                L = Math.min(Math.max(L * mulL + addL, 0f), 1f);
1402                A = Math.min(Math.max(A * mulA + addA * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1403                B = Math.min(Math.max(B * mulB + addB * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1404                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
1405                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
1406                final int idx = (int) (L * 255.999f) << 8 | (int)(256f * hue);
1407                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1408                if(dist * dist * 0x1p-16f >= (A * A + B * B))
1409                        return oklab(L, A + 0.5f, B + 0.5f, alpha);
1410                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1411                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1412                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1413                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1414                                                (int) (L * 255.999f));
1415        }
1416
1417        /**
1418         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1419         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.RandomXS128})
1420         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1421         */
1422        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1423                float L = random.nextFloat();
1424                float A = random.nextFloat();
1425                float B = random.nextFloat();
1426                while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1427                        L = random.nextFloat();
1428                        A = random.nextFloat();
1429                        B = random.nextFloat();
1430                }
1431                return oklab(L, A, B, 1f);
1432        }
1433}
